bibl.title: Letter from A.R. Hufford to Philip Showalter Hench, September 28, 1940

div1.p: Hufford provides information on the Dean Memorial Bridge in Grand Rapids, Michigan, and inquires about arthritis treatment.

div1.head: Letter from A.R. Hufford to Philip Showalter Hench, September 28, 1940
div1.opener:
A. R. HUFFORD, M. D.
505 MEDICAL ARTS BUILDING
GRAND RAPIDS, MICHIGAN
September 28, 1940
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
They have already sent you photographs of the
memorial tablet on the Dean Memorial Bridge, which
the Camera Shop states is legible enough to be read,
and therefore they did not make a separate transcription.

The common name for the bridge is the Fulton Street
Bridge, because it connects Fulton on the west
side and Fulton on the east side of the river. The
official name is the Dean Memorial Bridge, and so
voted by the city council in 1928. Should you desire
any further information regarding this, please let me
know.

I would like to inquire regarding the use of Gold-
Thiosulphate in the treatment of infectious arthritis.
Have you used it to any degree, and if so with what
success? Also the approximate frequency of dosage.
Do you consider the use of parentral vitamins B
complex of great help in the treatment of infectious
arthritis?
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, A. R. Hufford, M.D. arh;jf
